reviews.review_msg: Watched his YouTube videos
Prof was pretty easy and nice. There wasn't too much work in his class. There are easy discussions worth 20%, which are really nice. The TA's were fair markers as well. I would recommend.
The GOAT. that's it.

One of my favourite profs at SFU. He made this course interesting because he showed interest in it, too. I liked how the papers had extensive feedback on them, it helped set me up for the rest. However, the final quiz or exam (worth 25%) was kinda more difficult than anticipated. Otherwise, Evan is the man

Evan is a really nice guy. It's very obvious that he cares about his students. The papers are graded a bit hard but he kinda helps make it up by making it clear what is gonna be on the final. The discussions are important and helpful. Evan is always willing to have proper conversations and answer questions. Interesting course content.

Dr. McCuish really cares about his students & is overall a great professor. Really open to answering questions in depth to help students understand. A little bit of a tough marker on essays but overall course isn't too difficult if you attend the lectures ! Managed to get a decent grade without even looking at the textbook.

He's a nice and helpful guy but the final exam...so misleading. Its like he purposely mislead students into thinking it will be easy. Same with the papers, grading makes NO SENSE, they take off marks for anything and all he had to say was "its the hardest part of the class you'll have the exam to make up for it". Lol sure ok.

He is super nice and clearly cares about his content and students. Essays are marked extremely heavy and online discussion posts matter a lot. Since this class was hybrid, it was a little annoying to keep up with weekly content, but the content itself was super interesting. He is passionate and always answers questions in depth. Overall great!

Overall, great course and great instructor. Weekly discussion posts for participation and bi-weekly in person lectures. Composed of three papers and an oral presentation outlining the findings from one. Criteria for the papers and oral presentation are very vague but he does provide additional guidelines if you require them.

Great professor. Discussion questions for this class were important but I believe it's because it was a partially online course. Overall really good experience with this professor. Clear lectures, assignments and overall very organized.

The lectures are extremely fast-paced but he explains everything in detail and is more than happy to clarify anything that wasn't understood. His lecture slides were thorough but he talks a lot about stuff that isn't on the slides and gives hints about the exam questions, so attendance is important. TAs were very sweet too. I  recommend this class!
Prof was cool, but the rubric and guidelines for the papers were vague. If you have Kelley Massingale as a TA, oh boy... good luck getting a good mark.

Evan McCuish is the best prof I've ever had. Overall, lectures are fast-paced but very informative and he does stop for questions and to further explain a concept. Midterm and final were both multiple choice with the final having a few written questions. There is also a term paper and group project that reflects what is learned in the lecture.

Evan is a great prof and he loves this topic, which helps engagement during the long online lecture videos. There's lots of work for a 200-level online class, but it is manageable as a 4th class (maybe not as a 5th). Weekly discussion posts are an easy 100%, but the TAs are hard markers on the papers, which don't have clear guidelines.

GOAT professor. Super knowledgeable about psychopathy and psychological explanations to crime. Assignments/paper's are manageable, as long as you follow guidelines and go to tutorials. Also, ATTEND LECTURES... trust me attending lectures will ensure that you pass exams. 10/10 would take another class with Dr. Evan.

Evan was a fantastic professor. The workload was pretty average but not too hard, weekly discussions, 3 papers, and a take home final. Marking can be a bit unclear and hard sometimes, especially if you have a hard-marking TA. I had Hana Ryu, unclear explanations for her marking, and passive aggressive emails when asking for clarification.

Even is a great prof, he has lots of field research experience and incorporates that into his lectures making it very engaging. There is a fair amount of writing and for a 200-level course he does have high expectations for the papers however there is no final.

Dr. McCuish is one of my favourite profs so far! His lectures are interesting and to the point, and he lets you know when a topic will or will not be tested on. Assignments were easy, 3 papers and one presentation, expectations were clear. Exams were also very easy, only m/c questions. As a bonus, he called out anyone who was speaking too loud!
Very interesting course and enjoyed listening to his lectures. It's a great upper division course, although I almost wish that he graded on discussion/participation rather than strictly papers.

Evan is a good teacher. His tests are based on the lectures, so if you study the lectures you will do good on the tests. The only thing that I did not like in this class was how the papers were graded very harshly. He has very high expectations for the papers.  But other then that,  he was good and the TA was helpful.

Evan's lecture slides are organized really well and highlight what will be tested material often. If you take solid notes and study his quiz review slides the quizzes are really easy and no textbook material was tested.

3 papers will f you up, TA's mark so harsh and provides little to no explanation for it. they will mess up your grade hard, presentation + participation + 2 quizzes are the easiest part of the course (tho quiz 1 was harder than quiz 2). the strike also messed things up, but no consideration was given to that when it came to papers. 7/10.

While the class is interesting none of the in class lecture material is used for your assessment. Your entire grade is based off a term project including an annotated bib, 12 page paper and a presentation on your topic. The topic can have nothing to do with the course material. So what exactly did I learn? He is also a tough grader.
Great and interesting prof. His lectures were always engaging even if the audio is inconsistent sometimes.

Great prof. All lectures are on zoom and he is approachable outside class. His TA's can mark harshly though so make sure you do well on the papers. No midterms but weekly discussions are easy points. Not an easy A but it is an interesting course, textbook wasn't required but focus on the lecture materials.

Dr. McCuish is one of my favourite professors. His online lectures are long but interesting, and it is clear he knows his stuff. He uses examples from his own experiences which adds a lot of value to the course content. This class was very paper-heavy, but online weekly discussions are a good opportunity to do well. Overall, enjoyed this course.

He is amazing. He knows his material and knows exactly what to talk about in class without looking at his lecture slides. His exams are quite fair and easy, he will let you know what to focus on mostly. 95% of questions come from lecture material and 5% textbook. His assignment may look confusing but not hard enough to not achieve a good grade

He was a great professor. His class was interesting and very engaging. There were no weekly quizzes or heavy assignments except for the term paper, which if you start a little early, you'll do just fine. If you are interested in criminology and psychology, this is an interesting course, and he is a good professor.

Took this class online in Fall 2020 Great professor. I personally did not read the textbook for this class because Dr. McCuish's lectures were very informative and knowledgeable. Exams were fair and the final paper for this class was really engaging and marked fairly. Great guy.

I've taken 2 classes with Dr. McCuish and he was amazing! Both courses weren't assignment-heavy. Just a few short papers, one of the courses didn't even have a midterm, and then a final. He genuinely cares about his students and wants everyone to succeed. His TA's can mark hard so not an automatic A+ course, you do have to work for it!

Lectures on youtube are well-edited and easy to follow. He also includes video clips and memes that provide comic relief and aid in understanding the material. There are three 1500 word essays throughout the term, one presentation in weeks 12 or13 based on one of your papers, and a final exam. Nonetheless, he is one of my favourite teachers at sfu

Evan is definitely one of the better teachers at this school. He explains the topics well during lectures, which are on youtube. There are weekly discussion posts and three 1500 word essays throughout the semester. The class is not over yet; however my only issue is that there was no midterm exam, but there is a final which covers everything
Get ready for hundreds of pages of readings, little support, and mixed messages.

One of the best profs I've ever had! I took this course my first semester (Fall 2019), and it honestly was a great class to ease into university. He's really clear in what he expects on assignments/exams and makes the material so easy to comprehend. You can tell he genuinely cares about his students and does his best to make sure everyone succeeds.

Professor McCuish was one of my favourite professors. He gives a clear grading criteria of what he expects on the paper. He is available for help whenever you need, and gives good advice. His exams are decent, put the work in and you can easily receive a good grade.

Evan is probably my favourite professor from all 4 years of my undergrad. He is super passionate and helpful. He makes concepts very clear through a variety of ways of explaining them. His online lectures are actually interesting to watch... which honestly is a miracle because online lectures are the worst! Would highly recommend him!!

Prof McCuish is hands down one of the most caring and amazing lecturer on SFU. He engages with the students and uses memes to tie in with the course materials; he ensures that the material given were easy to understand and follow. He also cares for his students and wants them to succeed. TIP: He really really likes Natalie Portman haha

He is really passionate about crim. Explains well and has good analogies to help you understand the material. He's pretty quick at responding to emails and is good at clarifying things. He really cares about helping you succeed by even making an extra vid on how to write papers (since it's an intro course) and tips on how to cite. The TA was good 2

My fav first year prof and he's such a cutie! Was really understanding of COVID circumstances and understood that many students were feeling stressed. Only one assignment for the whole sem and the tests are straightforward. Lectures are also very interesting and he has a good way of connecting concepts that helps all students to understand it well.

One of my favourite first year profs. His lectures are very interesting and he tries to make them relevant to today's world. No assignments except one paper and he gives very clear criteria which makes it easier to do. He was very understanding of the COVID circumstances and accommodated to students. Highly recommend taking this class with him
Really captures your attention good at relating to younger millennials.

This is my first semester at sfu and i haven't even finished this course yet but he is by far my favourite prof. Super passionate about what he teaches which makes it easier to stay engaged during lectures. Tests and assignments are straightforward and he has a clear criteria for what he is expecting. Would 100% take any course with him again!

I really respect Evan and the way he designed this seminar course. I loved that a majority of the semester we got to spend learning about a topic we chose, and despite the theory part of the course being a bit boring I understand why it was necessary. The exam was really easy, and Evan was very clear about his expectations for all assignments.

He is very passionate about what he teaches, which makes the content less dry as it is is quite theory based. He does come off as being a bit arrogant but is willing to help and answer questions. the marking is pretty easy, just know his notes and you can get away without reading the textbook. would definitely take another class with him

Amazing prof, super passionate about teaching his stuff and knows it very well, has a good line of being fair to students but also doesn't take anything he really shouldn't student friendly overall loved taking his class and it was at 8:30 AM.
Evan was a great lecturer, he clearly cared about you learning and understanding the infromation. The exams were about 90% lecture material with 5 or so questions of stuff only from the textbook.

Evan is super cute and adorable but he marks really heavy. our first exam, i thought i did really well but there were quite a few trick questions and i ended up getting a 60% on that exam. tutorial is where you make up for that, the group project really helps, and participation. the textbook is useful because it touches on things that evan doesn't.
Sometimes give hints on what is going to be on the midterm/final in lectures. Group project was alright and got a fair mark. Term paper was very researched base.
He is one hell of a tough grader, but then again he is like the genius of the SFU crim department (google him and you'll see). His bromance with Mathesius is legendary.

Interesting lectures but exams can be a bit tricky, especially the multiple choice. He's looking for very specific answers that might just have been briefly mentioned in class. Make sure to attend lectures!

Very research-focused on presenting findings in lecture material, and the term paper is very heavy research-based. He's very serious and not very approachable but he is an engaging lecturer for an 8AM class.
terrible TA's will ruin this class.
I would 100% take another class with Evan. His lectures are interesting, even when the content is dry.
Lectures are just him reading off exactly what's on the powerpoint slides posted on canvas. The class was kind of boring and tutorials were pointless. But the class itself was easy enough.

Evan is a great prof for upper division Crim courses. You can tell he really cares about his students and is passionate about what he teaches. His directions can be a little confusing at times so go to office hours for clarification (only negative). Overall, if you put in the work you'll end up with a good grade.
he is very caring towards students, take a class with him if you can.  if you need help with soemething in the course he is always available

He's a young hottie, knowledgeable,  and passionate about topics. Gives breaks in lecture. Lectures can be SO BORING, but it's not his fault. Posts lecture slides. Group project in tutorial  is bad though.

While not the worst professor, it is evident that he is young (immature, childish) and inexperienced. I came across a discussion post where he responded (engaged) with a potential complaint. It would not surprise me if he monitored this site. People can't help others until they can first help themselves. Concerning behavior given his focus area.

He makes it pretty clear what is going to be on the test. Most of the materials from the test comes from his lectures, but probably around 5 questions come from the textbook (I think skimming it is decent enough). Very clear and easy grader. Easy to get along. His lectures are not boring. Make sure you go to his lectures.
Amazing prof. Midterm and final extremely fair, read the textbook.

You know your prof is cool when he responds to your email in less than 5 minutes. Evan is great at explaining things and his lectures are interesting to listen to. Tests are fair and unlike some other crim profs, tests on what you know & understand rather than have you purely memorize specifics. Super great bc he encourages critical thinking.
Great prof with a knowledge of the material. Group presentations in tutorial but grading is fair. Need the textbook because he tests off of it but he provides powerpoint notes!

Evan was a phenomenal lecture and his enthusiasm is contagious. Very engaging in a seminar course, incorporated so much current research, gave us the freedom to explore any topic in depth for our papers, and gave students the opportunity to apply what we were learn by assessing real case studies. I would recommend Evan to any student!

He is knowledgeable in what he is doing and I would recommend any CRIM students to take CRIM 103 with him. He explains well enough for you to understand the topics and will answer your questions if you have doubts.  Best prof I had for my very first CRIM course so far.

If you ever get the chance to take an upper level Crim class with Evan, do it.  Super knowledgeable, explains concepts really well, and is a really nice guy (he brought the whole class coffee one morning because people were up late writing their papers).  Super great prof, hopefully he stays when hes done his PhD.

Great prof. He's precise, he knows what he is talking about, and he explains thing in a way that is very easy to understand. the material is interesting and he makes it more interesting as well. I would highly recommend taking this course with Evan!

Evan is extremely knowledgable and passionate about what he does. His lecture slides are helpful when it comes time to study for the midterm and final, but don't skip the textbook readings. Overall an interesting course and he explains things clearly, would take another class with him
very nice
Complaint would be that he repeats himself a bit.
Okay
